summary: This is a formal request from the U.S. Department of Justice to the United Kingdom for mutual legal assistance in the prosecution of Ghislaine Maxwell. It seeks specific records (school, birth certificate, travel) related to a minor victim, referred to as 'De Georgiou', to corroborate her anticipated testimony about being groomed and abused by Jeffrey Epstein and Maxwell in the mid-1990s. The document outlines the charges, facts of the case, and the urgent need for evidence ahead of Maxwell's November 2021 trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the prosecution. The document details her alleged role in assisting Jeffrey Epstein in the sexual exploitation and abuse of multiple minor girls from at least 1994 to 2004.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as the primary perpetrator of sexual abuse of minor girls. The investigation into his conduct led to the charges against Maxwell. He was indicted in July 2019 and died by suicide in August 2019.

persons.name: De Georgiou
persons.context: A minor victim who Maxwell allegedly groomed in London between 1994 and 1995. Maxwell introduced her to Epstein, encouraged massages that led to sex acts, and invited her to travel. She is cooperating with prosecutors and is anticipated to testify at trial.

persons.name: Jason E. Carter
persons.role: Associate Director, Office of International Affairs
persons.context: Signed the request letter as the Associate Director of the Office of International Affairs, U.S. Department of Justice, Criminal Division.

connections.description: Maxwell is alleged to have conspired with, assisted, facilitated, and contributed to Epstein's sexual abuse of minors by recruiting, grooming, and arranging travel for victims.
Maxwell allegedly groomed and befriended the minor victim De Georgiou, introduced her to Epstein, and encouraged her to massage Epstein knowing it would lead to sexual abuse.
Epstein is alleged to have engaged in sex acts with the minor victim De Georgiou during massages arranged through Maxwell.

events.title: Grooming of Victim in London
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell groomed and befriended the minor victim De Georgiou in London, introduced her to Jeffrey Epstein, and encouraged massages that led to sexual abuse.

events.title: Epstein Indictment
events.description: A grand jury in the Southern District of New York returned an indictment charging Jeffrey Epstein with conspiracy to sexually traffic in minors and other crimes related to sexual abuse of minors.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein committed suicide in his jail cell while detained pending trial.

events.title: Maxwell Indictment
events.description: A grand jury in the Southern District of New York returned an indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell for her role in assisting Epstein's sexual abuse of minors.

events.title: Maxwell Superseding Indictment
events.description: A grand jury returned a Superseding Indictment charging Maxwell with additional counts, including sex trafficking conspiracy and perjury.

events.title: Scheduled Maxwell Trial
events.description: The trial in United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled to begin on this date, creating urgency for evidence collection.

locations: Collingham College (23, Collingham Gardens, London SW5)
Southern District of New York (40 Foley Square, New York)
keyFacts: The U.S. is urgently seeking UK records (school, birth, travel) for a victim named De Georgiou to corroborate her testimony in the Maxwell trial.
The victim De Georgiou was groomed by Maxwell in London in 1994-1995 when she was under 18, introduced to Epstein, and sexually abused during massages.
The document confirms the ongoing investigation into Epstein's network continued after his death, leading directly to Maxwell's indictment.
Maxwell is charged with conspiracy, transportation of minors, enticement, sex trafficking of minors, and perjury for false statements under oath.
The request emphasizes extreme confidentiality to prevent witness intimidation, evidence tampering, or alerting other subjects of the investigation.
